title: Hairline/thin serif that connotes luxury
content:
I have a weakness for the classy hairline, though usually I see them in sans more than serif. Even if you can’t ID, recommendations would be much appreciated. Thanks in advance.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830092856im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/40BONDLOGO_4131.gif)

 [‹ (x) Beautiful script in Suitcase Type Foundry Open Type Collection Catalogue - BistroScript {Yves}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830092856/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36711 "Go to previous forum topic") [Tattoo Font?? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830092856/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39178 "Go to next forum topic")
author: roquestrew

comments.content:
Do a search - “40 BOND” has come up way too many times in the past couple of years. I believe it was identified as a custom Caslon for the New York Times Magazine.

Stephen did [a piece](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830092856/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontfeed/archives/extra-thin-ultra-light-fonts/) in August about extra light type. There’s a section on extra light serifs you might like. Also check out [his entry](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830092856/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontfeed/archives/extra-bold-ultra-black-fonts/) from July about Extra Bold fonts, for the High Contrast section.

- Lex

ah I should’ve searched; I thought that because the 40 Bond project was a 2007 project, it would not have been too prominent on the type-ID boards

anyhow, thanks for the links!
